summary: The video ranks 20 popular back exercises from best to worst for muscle growth, evaluating them based on stretch, tension, feel, and progression potential. The video criticizes exercises that combine back work with other muscle groups, like renegade rows, and two-in-one combination exercises, due to the weaker muscle group limiting back stimulation. Deadlifts are acknowledged for building total body strength but placed in C tier for back-specific hypertrophy due to limited stretch and tension on the lats and mid-back. The video praises exercises like wide-grip pull-ups, neutral-grip pull-ups, various lat pulldown variations (wide-grip, neutral-grip, and half-kneeling one-arm), barbell rows, Pendlay rows, Meadows rows, and chest-supported rows for their effectiveness in back development. Inverted rows, dumbbell rows, and T-bar rows are discussed with their pros and cons, while cable lat pullovers and dumbbell lat pullovers are recommended for extra lat isolation volume. Ultimately, the chest-supported row is crowned as the best overall back exercise, while the renegade row is considered the least effective.

timestamps.description: Introduction: Ranking 20 back exercises for muscle growth
Criteria for an S-tier back exercise: stretch, feel, and progression
F-tier: Renegade rows and other two-in-one combination exercises (lack of stretch and tension)
C-tier: Deadlifts (limited stretch and tension on lats and mid-back)
A-tier: Wide-grip pull-ups and neutral-grip pull-ups (high tension, deep stretch, but tricky resistance profile)
B-tier: Chin-ups (some back tension shifted to biceps)
S-tier: Wide-grip lat pulldowns, neutral-grip lat pulldowns, and half-kneeling one-arm lat pulldowns (big stretch, smooth tension, good feel, and easy progression)
A-tier: Cross-body lat pulldowns (increased stretch, but awkward movement)
B-tier: Barbell rows (good stretch and tension, but less stable than other options)
C-tier: Yates rows (looser form and less stretch)
B-tier: Pendlay rows (higher degree of stretch and tension, but not as stable)
S-tier: Meadows rows (deep stretch, high tension, unilateral work)
C-tier: Inverted rows (good stretch and feel, but limited progression options)
A-tier: One-arm dumbbell rows (big stretch, good feel, but limited progression with heavy weights)
A-tier: Kroc rows (looser form, but controlled momentum and good stretch)
B-tier: Free-standing T-bar rows (good stretch and tension, but stability and balance issues)
S-tier: Chest-supported rows (stable, secure feel, high tension on lats and mid-back)
S-tier: Cable rows (close-grip and wide-grip variations, deep stretch, great pump, easy progression)
B-tier: Standard rope face pull (good stretch and mind-muscle connection, but unstable)
A-tier: Lying or seated rope face pull variations (eliminate balancing requirement, more tension on back)
A-tier: Cable lat pullover/lat prayer (huge stretch, strong mind-muscle connection, good for higher reps)
A-tier: Dumbbell lat pullover (more tension at bottom range, good for emphasizing stretch)
Best of the best: Chest-supported row (effective for lats and mid-back)
Worst of the worst: Renegade row (lack of stability for maximizing tension)
Recommendation for a science-based body building program
